thread.title: Lady Warhawks’ Kimble eyes college softball tenure
thread.title_full: Lady Warhawks’ Kimble eyes college softball tenure

author: Neighbor Newspapers (noreply@neighbornewspapers.com)
title: Lady Warhawks’ Kimble eyes college softball tenure
text: slideshow Even though the Henry County softball team failed to make it to post season play this year, first baseman Chelsie Kimble is not putting her bat and glove aside, not by a long shot.The Lady Warhawk senior, who concluded her high school softball career this year hitting .495 and driving in 21 runs, has received an invitation from Young Harris College to try out for a spot on its team.Her list of college softball tryout invitations is beginning to get a little crowded as she recently returned from a tryout at Samford College in Alabama.A member of the Lady Warhawks’ varsity unit since she was a freshman, Kimble said she would go just about anywhere for the opportunity to continue her softball career which, she said, ended too quickly this fall with the Lady Warhawks not advancing to post-season play.According to Lady Warhawk head softball coach Sarah Wilder, Kimble has been a leader on the softball team since she first stepped onto the field as a freshman.“What makes Chelsie a star are not only her outstanding skills at softball but, more importantly, her attitude,” Wilder said, calling Kimble the ideal athlete to have on a high school team.“A spectator watching Chelsie play would never know if the Lady Warhawks were winning or losing a game because of Chelsie’s positive, uplifting attitude, which is always present.”Although disappointed Henry County did not make the playoffs, Kimble said her team had a fine year.“Making the playoffs is always the goal when a team, regardless or the sport, starts the season,” said Kimble.“We may not have reached that goal but we had a talented team of girls this year that got along very well together, on or off the field, and had a passion for playing this game,” she said.Kimble’s RBI average was one of the main reasons Wilder had Kimble hitting fourth in the lineup, which is the valuable clean-up position in the batting order.When Kimble comes to the plate, she said she thinks not only of what the situation is with her team at that point in the game but what she can do about it from an offensive standpoint. “I know how many we may have on base and how our opponent has set its defense,” she said.“I work at getting our runners around and getting them in.” Share This Article | similar stories
